metadata.title: Hip Labral Tears
description: Hip injuries in sports account for 3.1% to 8.4%. Labral tears are present in 22–55%  of athletes with hip pain(1)

The hip labrum is a fibrocartilaginous structure that attaches to the bony rim of the acetabular socket.(1) The typical labrum is triangular in shape and varies from 1 to 10mm long;it blends inferiorly with the transverse acetabular ligament(1,2)

The primary functions of the hip labrum are shock absorption, joint lubrication, pressure distribution, and joint stability(1,10) –The labrum increases acetabular depth by approximately 20%(1) –The labrum seals the femoral head, limiting joint distraction, rotation, and translation, particularly at the extremes of motion. Authors of an in-vitro  fluoroscopy study found the labrum to act as a secondary stabilizer for external rotation and anterior translation, with the iliofemoral ligament acting as the primary stabilizer(1,10) –Synovial fluid is trapped centrally, creating fluid film lubrication that allows for pressurization of the cartilage interstitial fluid and load distribution(1)

A labral tear is an intraarticular lesion that results from acute trauma or repetitive femoroacetabular impingement (FAI), as in certain activities and sports. Hip labral tear typically occurs in the anterior portion of the labrum. The residual labral flap is unstable, is largely avascular, and has limited ability for self-repair(1)
Labral tears are classified into types A and B(2) –Type A: traumatic injury, triangular –Type B: degenerative, thick and rounded
There are three stages of a labral tear(2) –Intra-substance  degeneration –Partial tear –Complete tear
With a labral injury, the amount of force required to distract and displace the hip is significantly reduced,placing the hip at increased risk for joint instability

ICD-10 codes.S73.191A: Other sprain of right hip, right hip labrum tear, initial encounter
ICD-10 codes.S73.192A: Other sprain of left hip, left hip labrum tear, initial encounter (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms vary depending on the degree and severity of the tear. In some cases, the patient may report vague, nonspecific signs or symptoms
Pain is usually localized to the anterior hip-thigh  region. Discomfort/pain may also be in the posterior buttock and lateral hip, or radiate to the knee. Athletes with FAI may report groin pain(6)
Mechanical sensations such as clicking, catching, or locking, moreso when the hip is at a specific angle
Pain associated with decreased hip ROM, especially internal rotation, flexion, adduction, and abduction

Impaired functional activities due to pain, joint instability, and muscle weakness (e.g., reduced walking/running tolerance, sitting tolerance time, ability to don shoes)(10) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Three main categories: direct trauma, structural abnormalities, repetitive motions–Isolated tears most often result from high-velocity  direct trauma to the hip joint (e.g., contact sports, motor vehicleaccidents), with males more likely than femalesto cite an identifiable acute trauma(1)–Structural abnormalities/hip joint intraarticular pathological conditions such as FAI, capsular laxity, dysplasia, or chondrallesions can accelerate wear and tear of the joint(1)–Repetitive motions from sports-related  or other physical activities that often involve sudden twisting, cutting, or pivotingmotions can result in microtraumatic impact loading(1)-Extreme external hip rotation as in dancing (e.g., the “turned out” or second position with feet aligned to 180°) or icehockey may cause acetabular rim (cam) loading-Labral tear is a component of the so-called  sports hip triad (i.e., labral tear, adductor strain, and rectus femoris strain)reported in elite football (American football) players
pathogenesis: Labral tearing–Pincer-type  impingement causes labral degeneration tears from repeated contact of the anterior acetabular ring andfemoral neck(1)–Cam-type  impingement of the femoral head-neck  junction and acetabulum causes an outside-in  abrasion of the acetabularcartilage and delamination of labrum and subchondral bone(1)
Joint instability develops in conjunction with degenerative chondral lesions, especially in patients with structuralabnormalities of the hip joint

overall contraindications precautions: Recommend radiographs to rule out femoral fracture if patient is unable to bear weight on the involved extremity due to pain
Avoid hip extension past a neutral position to avoid increased forces through the anterior hip joint(16)
Follow surgeon’s orders for weight-bearing  and rehabilitation progression and any other orders after surgical intervention
Obtain specific instructions from the orthopedic surgeon for exercise and activity following surgery
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: The history can be nonspecific.(1) Document onset and progression of symptoms. Did an event precipitate the pain or other symptoms or was pain onset insidious? Is pain associated with certain hip positions or movement patterns? In general, are the symptoms getting better, worse, or staying the same?

course of treatment.medical management: Document conservative treatments, such as NSAIDs, relative rest, physical therapy, and restricted weightbearing(1)Arthroscopic surgery to remove the torn pieces of the labrum is usually indicated after a trial of unsuccessful conservative treatment(1) Over the past years, surgical management has progressed as a result of published biomechanical studies on the importance of the mechanical function of the labrum. Options include segmental labral resection, selective debridement, and labral reconstruction. The latter is recommended when the labrum is very damaged or worn too thin to be adequately functional(3) Authors of a study using human cadavers (N = 10) in the United States found that labral reconstruction with iliotibial band autografts and semitendinosus allografts increased labral contact area and improved hip joint biomechanics compared to labral resection(7)
course of treatment.medications: Document the medications (e.g., NSAIDs or other analgesics) clinician has prescribed, whether they are being taken, and if they are effectively controlling symptoms
diagnostic tests completed: Plain X-ray  radiographs are usually nonspecific but can be used in differential diagnosis (e.g., femur fracture, structural abnormality)(1)
Computed tomography arthrography (CT-arthrography)  demonstratedthe greatest overall accuracy in a systematic
Bone scan may have been indicated to rule out stress fracture, infection, or avascular necrosis
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy (land-based  or aquatic) for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ambulation, pivoting on impaired extremity, extended bouts of sitting, and impact activities (running, jumping) may aggravate the hip.(1) Is the patient able to drive without pain or discomfort?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain is often reported in the anterior hip-thigh area and/or groin(1,6)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Does the patient report clicking, catching, locking, or giving-way  sensations with weight-bearing  or ambulation?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to the condition. Is the patient able to find a comfortable sleeping position? Nocturnal pain may be reported(1)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, other joint pain, unexplained weight loss, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any known respiratory compromise (dyspnea on exertion)?Does the patient require the use of supplemental oxygen during the day? Is so, how much? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior history of hip, back, pelvic, or other lower extremity disorders?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, arthritis, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders (e.g., lumbosacral dysfunction/pain, hip dysplasia)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Patients are often prescribed NSAIDs for pain management
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing, such as dizziness, vertigo, pain at night, unexplained weight loss

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does patient participate in high-risk  activities such as running, golf, ice or field hockey, soccer, dance (ballet), or other competitive activities/sports? Does the patient’s work increase symptoms? If so, what are the physical job requirements (e.g., prolonged standing, prolonged sitting, driving, airplane travel)? How far can the patient ambulate and/or run prior to pain or discomfort?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient report any limitations with ADLs within the home or community? Is the patient currently using an assistive device for ambulation?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? With whom does the patient live?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Is BMI in the normal range for age and sex?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is the patient currently using any assistive device for ambulation? Does the patient use any adaptive devices for ADLs (e.g., to don socks or shoes)? Are the devices appropriate and being used correctly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance with the Berg Balance Scale (BBS). Can further test standing balance with perturbations, eyes closed, uneven surface
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess basic mobility skills: floor-to-stand,  sit-to-stand, and bed mobility. The FIM and/or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test can be used, as indicated
Modified Harris Hip Score (MHHH) can be used to assess functional outcomes following surgical intervention
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess gait biomechanics for any gait deviations associated with antalgia, such as decreased hip extension, decreased hip and knee flexion, decreased stance time, step length or stride length on involved extremity, or Trendelenburg sign(1)  –If patient has weight-bearing  restrictions, assess for ability to maintain precautions and ambulate properly within

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)

Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis
Open wounds, catheters, colostomies, IVs, G-tubes
More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions, and follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for recurrent falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Take special precautions to prevent falls while patient exercises, especially during functional training to improve posture, balance, and gait (e.g., use gait belt, parallel bars, or the assistance of another therapist when necessary)
Consider use of protective equipment such as hip pads to prevent further injury or reinjury when patient returns to sport
Following surgery, the patient should not perform the following until cleared by his or her orthopedic surgeon:

Evidence is lacking to support the use of physical or electrotherapeutic modalities for management of hip labral tears. However, modalities may be indicated to treat injuries related to trauma associated with the injury

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Hip labral tear/pain; reduced joint stability; reduced standing balance (with increased falls risk); reduced physical functioning in ADLs. Postoperative rehabilitation (inpatient and outpatient)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (1) Slipped capital femoral epiphyses Legg-Calve-Perthes  disease  Hip dysplasia Hip malignant neoplasm Iliotibial band syndrome Snapping hip syndrome Coxa profunda Protrusio acetabuli Avascular necrosis of head Stress fracture of femoral neck Trochanteric bursitis Lumbar radiculopathy Inguinal or femoral hernia Iliopsoas tendonitis Psoas bursitis Peripheral nerve entrapment Femoral artery thrombosis or dissection Femoral vein thrombosis
prognosis: Arthroscopic labral base repair (LBR) is a successful technique to restore the functional anatomy of the labrum and femoral head hydrostatic joint pressure, distribution of load and improved stability(11) –Authors of a case series of 60 patients (64 hips) who, at a minimum of 5-year  follow-up  in the United States, found 3 patient-reported  outcomes (PROs) including the modified Harris Hip Score (mHHS), Non-Arthritic  Hip Score (NAHS), Hip Outcome Score-Sport-Specific-Subscale  (HOS-SSS),  V AS, patient satisfaction and survivorship. Significant improved outcome scores were maintained compared to preoperative and 2-year  scores

Authors of a cohort study of clinical outcomes from three surgical techniques for labral repair concluded that from pre-op to 36 months post-op,  outcomes were not influenced by suture type(12) –Patients were grouped based on three labral repair techniques: sutures piercing through the labrum, looped around, or a combination of both techniques –Secondary outcomes of failure and revision rates were also not statistically different

Authors of a study in Canada reviewed arthroscopic surgical management and clinical outcomes of patients under age 25 treated for hip labral tears(15) –Labral tears in this patient population often occur without bony deformities and less cartilage damage than in persons with bony pathology –76 patients with 82 hips, mean age 20.4, underwent hip arthroscopy for treatment of labral-chondral  damage –At one-year  follow-up  WOMAC and Hip Disability and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS) were significantly improved

Authors of a study (N = 33) in the United States compared outcome measures (NAHS, Hip Outcome Score Activities of Daily Living Subscale[HOSADL], and mHHS) at a minimum of 2-year  follow-up  in patients with FAI who either underwent acetabular labral reconstruction (n = 11, RECON) or segmental labral resection (n = 22, RESEC)(3) –All outcome measures in both groups had statistically improved at follow-up  compared to preoperative measures –Significantly greater improvements for NAHS and HOSADL were found in the RECON group compared to the RESEC group –There were no other statistically significant differences in mean changes for outcome measures, although trends were all in favor of the RECON group

In 301 athletes identified in a systematic review of 10 articles, 87.4% of the 210 male athletes and 91 female athletes were able to successfully return to their pre-injury  level of competition at an average of 7.7 months after surgery(18) –A cost analysis comparing hip arthroscopic surgery versus structured rehabilitation for a patient with an acetabular labral tear without OA found that patients who were treated with arthroscopic hip surgery had a decreased likelihood of developing symptomatic hip OA. Arthroscopic surgery for a labral tear was 94.5% more cost-effective  than structured rehabilitation(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedic surgeon for patients with unsatisfactory outcomes after conservative treatment  Occupational therapist for rehabilitation in instrumental ADLs Aquatic therapist for pool program
treatment summary: Research is lacking on the effectiveness of various rehabilitation protocols for acetabular labral tear, whether in conservative therapy or after arthroscopic surgery.(1) For example, authors of a systematic review of 18 studies (N = 2,092 cases, with mean follow-up  of 3.2 ± 1.0 years) found that rehabilitation protocol parameters (e.g., weight-bearing,  motion, strengthening, and return to sport) were poorly reported and that differences in clinical outcomes could not be determined due to heterogeneity in study design(8)

A clinical commentary outlining rehabilitation following hip arthroscopy for FAI and labral-chondral  dysfunction describes a safe algorithm from immediate post-op  to return to sport that emphasizes tissue-healing  constraints as well as minimum criteria to advance (16)

Postoperative physical therapy is largely directed by the surgical procedure and individualized physician orders/guidelines, which typically emphasize strengthening muscles to optimize hip joint alignment, stability, and ROM; ergonomic assessment, restricting movement patterns that create shearing force on the labrum; balance and proprioceptive training; and gait reeducation, as may be indicated(16)
Weight-bearing  may be restricted by the physician as part of a conservative approach to treatment(1)

Researchers in the United states concluded that labral repair suture anchors may be able to withstand immediate physiological loads ofweight-bearingafter  surgery.The study was based on 3 cadaveric pelvises with 6 anterior-superior 1.5 cm tears and subsequent 2 suture anchor repair per hip. Simulated axial weight-bearing  was performed and the anchor repair was evaluated by testing load to failure(14)
Activity modification, including restricted weight-bearing  for at least 6 weeks, is usually indicated following surgical procedures

In a single-subject  research design study, conservative treatment of soft tissue therapy, active release technique, stretching, strengthening of the hip external rotators and abductors, improved posterolateral and anteromedial hip pain in patients with labral tears. Hip Outcome Score and V AS improved in all 4 patients treated for 6-8 weeks(17)

Aquatic physical therapy may be incorporated into the patient’s typical physical therapy regimen when significant pain is present with weight-bearing  and ambulation. This can be a part of preoperative or postoperative treatment intervention or as part of the recommended plan of care for conservative management . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain, discomfort Resolve pain Patient education _ The patient should not pivot on or forcefully rotate the affected extremity _ _ The clinician should address any atypical biomechanical movement patterns with the patient and provide education on the optimal way to complete various motions/activities _ _ Practice ADLs, ergonomic activities, and functional mobility skills with recommended movement patterns and positions to minimize hip joint pain and discomfort. Educate the patient on proper sitting alignmentN/A Make recommendations for home on pain management; provide handouts as indicated Reduced ROM (e.g., tight hip flexors, tight iliotibial band)Improve ROM Therapeutic exercises _ Implement ROM and stretching exercises as indicated. _ If accessible, implement aquatic therapy program for ROM exercisesProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedIncorporate ROM into home program as indicated Reduced muscle strengthImprove strength Therapeutic strategies _ Implement a strengthening program as indicated with special attention to hip flexor strength, if indicated(6) _ _ Aquatic-based exercises may be usedProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedIncorporate strengthening into home program as indicated  Postural deviations Normalize posture as ableTherapeutic strategies _ Lumbo-pelvic posture training _ Interventions to improve lower extremity alignmentProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedIncorporate postural challenges into home program as indicated Impaired gait/function Improve gait/function Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Brief trial of crutches or cane to limit weight-bearing; obtain physician parameters/ orders regarding weight-bearing status _ _ Therapeutic strategies _ Address any noted gait deviations _ Aquatic therapy may be used for gait training, increasing endurance, and increasing functional strengthWean from assistive device as indicated and permitted by physician ordersIncorporate ambulation into home program as indicated Problems after arthroscopic surgery include pain, reduced ambulatory function, swelling, hip joint hypomobility, muscle tightness, decreased strength, and reduced balance _ _Address impairments following surgical interventionManual therapy _ Graded capsular mobilization to restore hip ROM after surgery _ _ Therapeutic strategies _ Implement therapeutic strategies as indicated by the patient’s needs _ _ Obtain weight- bearing orders from physician and any other restrictions following surgeryProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home program as indicated .

maintenance or prevention: Continue hip and core strength training to prevent lower extremity injuries in general

Sport-specific  training should be continued once patient has consistently demonstrated the necessary strength, conditioning, and dynamic stability for a safe return to sport. Medical clearance is ultimately given from the referring orthopedic surgeon
patient education: See “Femoroacetabular Impingement (FAI)” from the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, http:// orthoinfo.aaos.org/topic.cfm?topic=A00571

See “Hip Labral Tear” from the Mayo Clinic, http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hip-labral-tear/home/ovc-20270126 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
